property.name: Survey Point
property.description: This is the spatial location assigned to the artefact(s) by one of the surveying instruments. Select the number from the field slip as it appears in the drop down list. This will automatically fill in the easting, northing and elevation data.

property.name: Field ID
property.description: This is the number assigned to the artefact(s) by the field recorder. Enter this from the field slip.

property.name: Catalogue Number
property.description: This is an automatically generated number. Each number is usually prefaced by a two letter prefix which refers to the site’s name, e.g. FN (Flinders North) 0001 (Artefact 1). DO NOT EDIT THIS INFORMATION.

property.name: Easting
property.description: Data sourced from internal/external GPS.

property.name: Northing
property.description: Data sourced from internal/external GPS.

property.name: Elevation
property.description: Data sourced from internal/external GPS.

property.name: Glass ID
property.description: Glass ID

property.name: Diagnostic
property.description: Does the fragment conform to one of the elements in the box above?

property.name: Colour
property.description: Use the drop down list provided. If in doubt consult the SHA historic bottle guide online.

property.name: Completeness
property.description: How much of the original artefact is present.

property.name: Frag Location
property.description: Where, on the original vessel, the fragment originates.

property.name: Vessel Type
property.description: Description of object.

property.name: Tableware Type
property.description: This is to record domestic tableware glass from vessels/items other than bottles. It is not applicable to bottles.

property.name: Frag Length
property.description: Length in mm is recorded for relevant artefacts only (i.e. usually only those that are sufficiently complete, or for which this is a meaningful measurement). Often only the maximum dimension is recorded.

property.name: Frag Weight
property.description: Weight in grams is recorded for all artefacts.

property.name: Frag Width
property.description: Width in mm is recorded for relevant artefacts only (i.e. usually only those that are sufficiently complete, or for which this is a meaningful measurement). Often only the maximum dimension is recorded.

property.name: Frag Thickness
property.description: Thickness in mm is recorded for relevant artefacts only (i.e. only for those for which this is a meaningful measurement, such as ceramic and bottle body shards, or window glass). Often only the maximum dimension is recorded.

property.name: Grouped Frag
property.description: Selecting yes will open a new tab for you to record information.

property.name: Number of Frags
property.description: FOR UNDIAGNOSTIC BODY SHERDS ONLY. Record the number of undiagnostic fragments to be included under the one Catalogue Number. These must be from the one type of bottle – e.g. dark brown bottle glass, olive green bottle glass, etc.

property.name: Group Weight
property.description: A total weight in grams for all of the sherds together.

property.name: Group Max Length
property.description: The length of the longest sherd in the group.

property.name: Group Max Width
property.description: The width of the widest sherd in the group.

property.name: Group Max Thickness
property.description: The thickness of the thickest sherd in the group.

property.name: Group Min Length
property.description: The length of the shortest sherd in the group.

property.name: Group Min Width
property.description: The width of the narrowest sherd in the group.

property.name: Group Min Thickness
property.description: The thickness of the thinnest sherd in the group.

property.name: Base Diameter
property.description: A measurement in millimetres of the external base diameter.

property.name: Base Thickness
property.description: A measurement in millimetres of the thickest portion of the base.

property.name: Kick Up Depth
property.description: A measurement in millimetres of the external depth of the kickup (i.e. from the external heel to the centre of the kickup [also referred to as pushup] on the outside of the base).

property.name: Metal ID
property.description: Metal ID

property.name: Metal Type
property.description: Records type of metal in question. Copper alloy is a mixture of metals. It is a generic term for those alloys made up of copper blended with tin (bronze), zinc (brass) or lead, or other metals. It will not be magnetic and may have a bluish, greenish or reddish hue. Nickel silver is used extensively as a base metal on silver-plated flatware, hence the common abbreviation EPNS (Electro Plated Nickel Silver) or EPGS (Electro Plated German Silver). It is resistant to corrosion and is not magnetic. Sheffield Plate, was formally patented for industrial use by Thomas Bolsover of Sheffield in 1742. Iron will rust and will often be highly corroded in an archaeological context. It will be magnetic. Lead will be much heavier and will often form a white soft layer of corrosion over its surface.
